citation.article-title: Shuttleworthia satelles gen. nov., sp. nov., isolated from the human oral cavity.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Shuttleworthia (Shutt.le.wor'thi.a. N.L. n. Shuttleworthia named to honour Cyril Shuttleworth, the distinguished British microbiologist)
Cells are obligately anaerobic, non-spore-forming, non-motile, slightly curved, Gram-positive, short bacilli.
Cells are saccharolytic, and the principal end products of glucose metabolism are acetate, butyrate and lactate.
Growth in broth media is good and is stimulated in the presence of fermentable carbohydrates.
Aesculin is hydrolysed and indole is produced.
Nitrate is not reduced; arginine and urea are not hydrolysed.
Gelatin is not liquefied and H2S and catalase are not produced.
There is no growth in 20% bile.
The G+C content of the DNA of S. satelles, the only species so far described in this genus, is 51 mol%.
The type species is Shuttleworthia satelles.
